article:
The 'Office of Regulatory Affairs
(ORA)' [http://www.fda.gov/AboutFDA/CentersOffices/ORA/ U.S. FDA Office of
Regulatory Affairs] is the part of the U.S. Food and Drug Administration
(FDA) that enforces the laws governing biologics, cosmetics, drugs, food,
medical devices, radiation-emitting electronic devices, tobacco products, and
veterinary products which may have potentially harmful side effects for the
consumer. [http://www.fda.gov/RegulatoryInformation/ U.S. FDA Regulatory
Information]

The FDA Office of Regulatory Affairs is responsible for the enforcement of
federal legislation and serves in a regulatory capacity to ensure health
related products are accurately and informatively represented to the public,
effective, and safe.

The Office of Regulatory Affairs has legislative and regulatory authority for
the specified health related products:

* Biologics [http://www.fda.gov/BiologicsBloodVaccines/ Vaccines, Blood &
  Biologics Regulatory Information]
* Cosmetics [http://www.fda.gov/Cosmetics/ Cosmetics Regulatory
  Information]
* Drugs [http://www.fda.gov/Drugs/ Drugs Regulatory Information]
* Foods [http://www.fda.gov/Food/ Foods Regulatory Information]
* Medical Devices [http://www.fda.gov/MedicalDevices/ Medical Devices
  Regulatory Information]
* Radiation-Emitting Electronic Products [http://www.fda.gov/Radiation-
  EmittingProducts/ Radiation-Emitting Products Regulatory Information]
* Tobacco Products [http://www.fda.gov/TobaccoProducts/GuidanceComplianceRe-
  gulatoryInformation/ Tobacco Products Regulatory Information]
* Veterinary Products [http://www.fda.gov/AnimalVeterinary/ Animal &
  Veterinary Regulatory Information]
